comments.commentBody: Steve Jobs made things easy to use for people. Marissa Mayer made yahoo mail harder to use after her arrival on the job. There ends the comparison. No contest on who the winner is.

Why does the sex of a CEO matter? Would it matter if the NYT ran an article about male CEO's who performed as badly?

As an investor, I want a CEO, male or female, who is an experienced leader that motivates people, acts as a professional and delivers results! Mayer appears more focused on herself. Standing up appointments, starting meetings late and not returning calls/emails is unprofessional and shows disrespect for associates/employees/clients.

Yes, lucked into the right place right time, and then coasted from there, with the help of others in the same boat who can't see the forest for the trees and mistakenly think they earned their windfall fortunes.  Her hiring Henrique de Castro for 15 months for $109 million is just the kind of craziness that results.  She revamped the main Google page to be minimalist... fine.  But it's something countless other web designers could have done.  The idea that it means she can run a company is just silly.

We can conclude an enormous amount. Orbital variation, sunspots, albedo, and many other things--volcanic activity, water vapor content of the air, cloud coverage, many many more factors--have all been included in the climate models, which have been built painstakingly by very intelligent people for decades. It's not like they overlooked some obvious factor that will be revealed in a two paragraph comment in a newspaper.

All the models say the same thing: anthropogenic climate change is undeniable and progressing at a shocking rate. Don't trust me, read the studies. The ones by scientists, not radio announcers or right-wing economists.

Over the history of our planet there were many times when we had Ice ages and melts. But we are talking about millions/billions of years. When people refer to global warming because of Human activity, I think they generally refer to a time frame of hundreds of years.
It is amazing to see how some people mix the two very skillfully to make their point. Who can blame them when our congressional leaders hide behind "I am not a scientist" phase to further their agenda.
It is a classic example of Frog in a tub of warming water.

Last Nov. 11, the NYT published an op-ed,  by a NASA scientist, Piers Sellars. In it he recounts a meeting with Steve Stockman (R Texas)  who claimed that scientists couldn't explain the ice ages.  Sellars replied that science understood the ice ages quite well as well as the earth's wobble, which occurred over such a long period of time that it's irrelevant for understanding short order anthropogenic climate change.  Thinking that he had laid to rest the misinformation of the congressman,  Dr. Sellars was surprised to discover that in a Congressional hearing, Stockman repeated the same false information that  had been decisively refuted. The only question is:  Why are  these falsehoods repeated?  Perhaps they are an indication of the failure of the educational system to teach the fundamentals of science.  The nation needs both producers of science as well as educated consumers of science.  Those who persistently falsify scientific findings do a disservice to both themselves and to the nation at large.

Those glaciers on Mount Kenya are retreating, alright, but now the question comes to mind: What's worse? Retreating glaciers? Or advancing ones?
We've had periods of both on this sun-orbiting rock, mostly long before anything resembling apes (let alone the naked kind, i.e. us) were around. So what explains that? No, dinosaurs weren't driving SUVs. (Imagine the roads THAT would have required!) But apparently the earth's axis did some wobbling and the sun's intensity, and sunspot activity, did some varying. How much could any creatures on this planet have affected that? Less than your chance of getting a genuine U.S. 1933 St Gaudens $20 gold coin in your pocket change.
So what can we conclude about all this, and our effects on climate change? See the last sentence in the previous paragraph for your answer.

Laura Hillenbrand is not only an award winning author, but someone living with a chronic devastating illness which has not only misunderstanding, but inadequate treatment, connected to it. The general "well" public is clueless as to what great lengths those with chronic illness go through on a daily basis just to exist in some form of "normal", let alone achieve success in a chosen career. Sometimes, I think that many people cannot wrap their minds around what it truly means to live with a constant devastating illness, so they make up their own rationalizations, "theories", irrational diagnoses, etc. to pin on the chronically ill. Seeing illness in someone else, imo, really brings out deep seated fears, especially when it comes to illnesses which are not easy to understand.

When greatness is achieved, that is to be celebrated, not picked apart. A person is not their chronic illness. They are like everyone else, just wishing to have the best life possible. To achieve a successful writing career while doing battle with both serious illness and relentless scrutiny, is even more cause for celebration.
Yes Susan. Girls are made of sugar and spice.

Big comment part 1:

This, of course, relates to Wallace neutrality, and the deviations from the assumptions in the real world are really consequential. I think I've now really nailed Wallace's model, and hope to soon do my big post on the intuition (and what goes wrong in the RW), but here's a taste:

Suppose in Wallace's model, there's a QE, a tiny one. The government prints up a dollar and buys some financial asset with it. In Wallace the choices are just state-price contracts, and buying and storing/investing the composite consumption good (which I call C's) for a return of x. So, suppose the government prints up this dollar and buys contracts for the delivery of C's in state i, at the current equilibrium market prices. We assume the economy starts in complete equilibrium.

Some guy buys this dollar in exchange for some state i contract(s) at the current market prices. Now, why does he do that? Why doesn't the market price move in response to the increased demand from the government for state i contracts? And why doesn't the price of dollars drop in response to the increased supply, and the government selling a new one?
You have to solve the puzzle before you know what's in it.

Big comment part 2:

Because, in a large sense, Wallace rigged the game with his requirement equations (a) and (b) of the Irrelevance Proposition. (b) says that, essentially, next period the government will buy back this dollar with the state i contracts' payouts, and any extra C's necessary, and any profit/loss from this QE in this next period will be given to one or more citizens in increased/decreased transfers net of taxes.

The person(s) this future profit/loss is foisted on will completely reverse it in the present with state price contracts (markets are assumed complete and frictionless). Why? Because requirement (a) of the Irrelevance Proposition requires that any QE, any monetary/fiscal maneuvers, leave every one with the same exact net present value of their endowment (their transfers minus taxes) at the current equilibrium state-prices – Thus, the QE cannot change the budget constraint of any individual. And if their budget constraint will not change, and the state prices and other asset prices don't change, then they will choose the exact same state-dependent consumption path as before, since we started in equilibrium with all individuals perfectly optimizing with their perfect foresight and other super-powers.

Big comment part 3:

Thus, they will just reverse anything the government does. The guy(s) this profit is foisted on, will just reverse it 100% with the purchase (or shorting) of state-price contracts. Likewise the guy who bought that dollar for state i contracts will take the other side of those people's state price contract purchases because he needs to do the exact opposite to neutralize his transaction of purchasing that dollar and get him back to his previous perfectly optimized consumption path. The ones who got the profit/loss foisted on them, short that profit/loss with state-price contracts. The guy who bought the dollar actually wants that profit/loss to get him back to his original optimal consumption path, so he takes the other side of their transactions.

This is one of the most sensible articles Krugman has written, and I can only quibble with the details. The model in which he distills borrow-to-spend decisions down to a battle between the real interest rate and time preference is hardly convincing since we know anticipated future income is more important, especially for investment. The real lesson from 2010-2011 is that despite a lot of people's initial expectations that QE would generate inflation, it didn't. What is Krugman saying, that QE would have worked if there had only been more inflation hysteria? Come on.

Where QE does have obvious effects is on relative asset prices. Obviously there is a hot-potato effect, driving the value of cash down relative to other assets. This was Bernanke's logic which he expressed in terms of pushing investors into riskier investments. It seems though not fully predictable which they'll pick: US QE didn't seem to generate much dollar devaluation relative to other currencies, whereas Japanese QE caused big, sudden yen devaluations.

You may wish to re-read the details of that case. Nakoula Basseley Nakoula had been arrested a number of times, but the only one that concerns us here is his conviction (he pled guilty) to a financial fraud scheme involving opening a series of online accounts under various aliases. Conditions of his parole included restricted internet access and a ban on using an alias for anything.
He was arrested and jailed for violating those two conditions of his parole. He plead guilty to four charges, was sentenced to another year in prison. He is currently in a supervised release program.
Not much there about free speech, eh?

If you read anything about how the jailed film-maker made his film, and who financed him, you would understand the film was made as a deliberate provocation, and that the intention was to provoke violence. None of the actors hired for the film were ever told the truth about what the film was for, and in fact were led to believe the film was something entirely different than what it was for.

The film was not an exercise in free speech. The film was an exercise in sabotage. That Hillary Clinton treated it as such was appropriate.

Do you feel the same way about the television commercial broadcast against Ms. Clinton in 2008 by the group called Citizens United?
Political speech cannot be censored because of its content. Period.

Where was Clooney and his Obama fundraising pals when Hillary had the filmmaker who released an unfavorable short about Mohammed jailed in California, right after Benghazi?
It's easy to support free speech we agree with; the First Amendment was written to protect speech we disagree with.
Your last paragraph: bingo.

NATO is a membership club. Nations apply to join. NATO didn't expand to Russia's borders. Nations along Russia's borders chose to join NATO as Russia did not offer a compelling or interesting alternative.

As for your assertion that the newly minted oligarchs in Russia were communist and KGB is patently untrue. All the oligarchs at the time were all very young, many in their 20s, as they saw the light and did what they could to steal the nation's resources from the people.

The communists at the time were too hidebound by ideology to even think of trying to run a capitalist company. As for the former KGB, they are only recently becoming filthy rich by using their relationships with Putin to steal companies and assets.

When Putin came to power, he was just a bit player in the grand scheme and rather poor. It was only with his ruthless control of the FSB, the successor to the KGB, and the military that he was able to wrest control from the oligarchs and bring about economic stability.

And Putin is still using the power of the corrupt judiciary to punish those who dare oppose him or stand in the way of him or his most inner circle cronies.

I wholeheartedly agree that the West's expansion of NATO to Russia's border was a provocative mistake that contributed to Putin's rise to power; but I don't agree that he isn't afraid of the expanded NATO. Russian leaders throughout history felt menaced by any gathering force on her borders.

But I don't think that's the full story of how Putin rose to the top. Encouraged by Chicago School economists eager to create an Ayn Rand society (how ironic that this former Russian came back to bite), Russia plunged from communism to a laissez-faire cowboy economy, selling off state assets at fire-sale prices; by no accident at all, the newly minted oligarchs were former Communist and KGB characters in Soviet days, and Putin was in the same network. The network lives on in the new not-so-improved Russia, other than for those members who were purged out because Putin considered them a threat.

As an aside, the admiration of Putin among American righties is quite revealing of how they really would like this country to be governed. Their professed reverence for the constitution masks an ugly authoritarian streak.

@azlib: Those weren't just "hissy fits" being thrown in response to criticism of the Iraq War. They were vicious accusations of a lack of patriotism and a failure to support the "troops." They were also direct threats against people's livelihoods. Ask Susan Sarandon, Martin Sheen and Bill Maher.

I've recently been watching some old TV series on DVD, including "Quincy, M.D.," "Perry Mason" and "Maude." I've been struck by how mature the subject matter often is, as well as the language in which it is discussed. Conservatives have purged almost all serious adult content out of broadcast TV. Nobody is allowed to openly discuss abortion any longer, for example, and heaven forbid that a popular leading character undergo the procedure.

Sanctimonious right-wingers have imposed more censorship in this country than progressives ever have. Much more.
Wasn't it Egyptian television that dramatized "The Protocols of Zion" for a huge TV audience one Ramadan?

Having Egyptian background, I am acutely aware of the negative portrayals of Arabs in movies, as terrorists.  Yet I would never support censorship or any intimidation for producing the offensive material; free speech is a liberty that I can't relinquish or take for granted.  My choice responses to offensive depictions are (a) Not to see it; (b) use the same First Amendment rights myself; (c) conduct myself in such a way that others recognize I'm not a hijacker or the like.  But muzzling and threatening are not acceptable courses in a democratic, pluralistic society, which North Korea clearly is not, but they can't take that from the US.

Nothing turns a libertarian into an authoritarian more quickly than the sight of an individual or company who refuses to martyr themselves in the defense of freedom of expression. Asking Sony to committ hara-kiri to protect the 1st amendment doesn't quite jibe with my understanding of  capitalist ideology. Sony's purported cowardice is more accurately described as prudence.

Whenever I read an opinion piece that up front trots out the "We live in a time" lament I know what I'm in store for. In this case, it's full-throated whining about a decline in free speech. Thing of it is, there's more free speech today than ever before. Everyone's a critic; two critics are a "Twitter mob." Electronically delivered death threats are so common they hardly merit a glance.

I happen to agree with Douthat that people in general are over sensitive, quick to take umbrage, but it is by no means a liberal thing. He should spent some time on unmonitored reader comment boards. (The NYT reader comment board is a Socratic discussion by comparison.)

Douthat did not mention Bill Donahue, head of the Catholic League and indefatigable scold about the slightest slight to the Catholic Church, not to mention generalissimo in the war against the war on Christmas. Scolds are everywhere. Today Douthat, uncharacteristically I might add, became one. Daniel Buck

"This is just a craven collapse of a large corporation weighing money against principal."

I thought with respect to corporations that money IS the principle? Have I been misinformed?

"This is just a craven collapse of a large corporation weighing money against principal."

It is craven. However, profit is the sole and ultimate goal of any corporation.

I think you meant to write "weighing money against principle," not "principal." "Principal" is kind of the same thing as money. And, in fact, that's what corporations do weigh: Money against money, specifically more money versus less money.

More money indeed is the principle of corporations.

This is as far from political correctness or a desire to avoid insulting someone as it possibly could be. This is just a craven collapse of a large corporation weighing money against principal. They blew up the leader of North Korea (at least figuratively). Yes, he is a bad dude, but this surely suggests that the issue of offending the North Koreans did not enter into the equation.
Although I am disgusted with Sony, I am certain this has nothing to do with Sony being PC. It's also a bit of a disappointment that free speech issues should arise around such a piece of cinematic garbage.

It was not Netanyahu's, but Ariel  Sharon's decision to pull the settlers out of Gaza. They left a solid infrastructure behind, which the Palestinians flattened to the ground. Only Hamas flourished there. It is one of the three richest terror organizations in the world. The poor Palestinians don't get  one red cent of the billions poured into Gaza.
It was Sharon, not Netanyahu, who pulled the settlers out of Gaza.

I stand corrected: it was, indeed, Prime Minister Sharon who uprooted the settlers in Gaza.  Netanyahu was opposed to his doing so. Hopefully we'll get to find out whether our politicians are ready to break with AIPAC.

You have to wonder what American politicians would do if the Israelis actually did elect a Labor Party government so committed to a two-state solution that it would actually sacrifice land for peace.  Would they continue to take their marching orders from the armchair quarterbacks of AIPAC whose leaders would no doubt vilify such an agreement?   Some of them are still denouncing Netanyahu's decision to pull the settlers out of Gaza some years back.  Hopefully our President and at least some members of Congress will rediscover their backbones if and when the Israelis discard the yoke of Likud.
There is no such thing as N. Korean sympathizers here in this country. They simply don't exist. Your problem with people walking into theaters with guns could be solved with banning guns in theaters.

I don't think it's politically correct to suggest that you shouldn't whack a hornet's nest. There are some seriously crazy people out their, including Muslim religious fanatics and North Korean dictators, who may react to insults, real or perceived, with violence. It may be that insulting such people is our constitutional right, but that does not make it any less foolhardy.

It would be easy for North Korean sympathizers to enter a theater with semiautomatic weapons and hundreds of rounds of ammunition. In fact, in much of the country they could do so legally, and if you tried to stop them you could be accused of racial profiling.

So my big question for Sony, when they decided to make this film, is "what the hell were you thinking?" That Kim Jong Un is rational? That he can take a joke? He isn't, and he can't. And he has nuclear weapons.
